title-group.article-title: Surface roughness analysis in high-speed drilling of unreinforced and reinforced polyamides

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Industrial and Production Engineering, B. V. B. College of Engineering and Technology, Karnataka, India
2Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, B. V. B. College of Engineering and Technology, Karnataka, India
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte MG, Brazil
4Department of Mechanical Engineering and Industrial Management, School of Technology, Polytechnic Institute of Viseu, Viseu, Portugal
5Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Aveiro, Aveiro, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: VN Gaitonde, Department of Industrial and Production Engineering, B. V. B. College of Engineering and Technology, Hubli-580 031, Karnataka, India Email: gaitondevn@yahoo.co.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this work, surface roughness study in high-speed drilling of unreinforced polyamide (PA6) and reinforced polyamide with 30% of glass fibers (PA66 GF30) using cemented carbide (K20) tool has been carried out. The experiments were planned as per full factorial design of experiments. The effects of cutting speed and feed rate on centerline average surface roughness, maximum peak to valley height, and peak counts have been analyzed by developing response surface methodology based third-order mathematical models. The parametric analysis clearly indicates the influence of reinforced fiber on surface finish when high-speed cutting in drilling is used.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The polyamides are thermoplastic polymer composites extensively used in a variety of applications in different fields of engineering such as aircrafts, automobiles, robots and machines due to excellent property profile thereby replacing many traditional metallic materials. The favorable properties include high specific strength and stiffness, wear resistance, dimensional stability, low weight, and directional properties. The polyamides physically differ in terms of melting point, glass-transition temperature, crystallinity and tensile modulus, among the other things. The PA66 polyamide has a melting point of 262°C, which is higher than that of PA6 at 219°C; its glass-transition temperature is 65°C versus 52°C for PA6; the crystal structure of PA66 is triclinic, while PA6 has a monoclinic structure and its tensile modulus is around 2.9 GPa, while it is a little lower for PA6.

The addition of short fibers to polyamides improves the properties over unreinforced polyamides. The stiffness, strength, and hardness of reinforced plastics are much greater than that of unreinforced thermoplastics. The inclusion of fibers also can often provide a useful increase in maximum service temperature. The glass fibers are the common reinforcements, which significantly reduce the expansion rate and increase the flexural modulus of PA6. On the other hand, glass fiber reinforced polyamide is highly abrasive when machined and brings out many undesirable results such as rough surface finish, rapid tool wear and defective subsurface layer with cracks and delaminations. Further, the cutting mechanism of unreinforced and reinforced polyamides is quite different from that of metals and hence the successful performance of machining operation is greatly affected by work material properties. As a result of improved properties and potential applications of both unreinforced and reinforced polyamides, there is a need to understand the manufacturing processes, particularly in machining of these composites.1

Some researchers have performed experimental investigations on machining of unreinforced and reinforced polyamides. Mata et al.2 carried out an experimental investigation on machining of unreinforced polyamide (PA6) and reinforced polyamide with 30% of glass fibers (PA66 GF30) using polycrystalline diamond (PCD) tool. The influence of glass fiber reinforcement on friction angle, shear plane angle, normal and shear stresses, and chip deformation under cutting conditions (cutting speed and feed rate) has been reported. The experimental model has also been compared with Merchant’s theoretical model. Davim and Mata3 also performed experiments on turning of PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides with cemented carbide (K15) tools. The influence of glass fiber reinforcement on friction angle, shear plane angle, normal and shear stresses, and chip deformation under the cutting conditions was observed. Further, the experimental physical model was also compared with Merchant’s equation. Gaitonde et al.4 used Taguchi’s quality loss function for simultaneously minimizing power and specific cutting force during turning of PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides. Gaitonde et al. 1 also applied response surface methodology (RSM) to analyze some aspects of machinability, namely, machining force, cutting power, and specific cutting pressure during machining of PA6 and PA66 GF30 with cemented carbide (K10) tool. Recently, the artificial neural networks models were developed by Gaitonde et al.5 to analyze the effects of work material, tool material, cutting speed, and feed rate on machining force, power and specific cutting force during turning of PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides. It was revealed that the machinability is poor in reinforced polyamide as compared to unreinforced polyamide.

Several works have also been published to evaluate the effect of cutting parameters and drill geometry on machinability of FRPs such as epoxy or polyester matrices reinforced with aramid, glass or carbon fibers.6,7 Among the damages induced by drilling, delamination is probably the most severe and therefore, a number of works have been concentrated on quantifying the damage level at the entrance and exit of the drill.8–13. Palanikumar et al.14 used design of experiments (DOE) to investigate the effect of process parameters on surface roughness during turning of glass fiber reinforced plastics (GFRP) composites. The research findings indicated that feed rate is the principal factor affecting surface roughness, followed by cutting speed.

According to Guu et al.15 conventional machining techniques damage the workpiece through chipping, cracking, delamination, and high wear on cutting tool. The structure for aerospace and automotive applications contains holes for various purposes such as bolted and riveted joints and these joints are used to transfer load within the structure. As reported by Persson et al.,16 the quality and accuracy of the holes greatly affect the joint strengths.

In the recent past, high-speed cutting (HSC) has been introduced in advanced manufacturing technology for achieving high productivity and to save the machining cost. The HSC leads to lower forces and higher material removal rate, which in turn minimizes the energy consumption. Hence, an introduction of increased cutting speeds along with special geometry tools utilized in drilling process has stimulated several researchers to investigate the various aspects of drilling composite materials. The effect of high speed (9550–38,650 rpm) on average thrust force, torque, tool wear, and hole quality for multifaceted and twist drills during drilling of carbon fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP) composites has been investigated by Lin and Chen.17 It was reported that an increase in cutting speed decreases the cutting force, which in turn minimizes the delamination thus increasing the production rate. The relationship between the thrust force and amount of damage was also established in their study. Recently, the delamination tendency in high-speed drilling of CFRP composites was studied by Gaitonde et al.18 and Karnik et al.19 considering the speed, feed, and point angle as the affecting parameters. It was reported that the delamination can be minimized by employing the higher speed with lower values of both feed rate and point angle.

The components made out of polyamides are usually near net shaped, thus requiring holes for assembly integration. When holes are produced on polyamide boards, special attention should be paid, in particular, for the automotive industry, as the machining parameters influence the surface roughness. The surface roughness is the measure of technological quality of a product and also an index for evaluating the productivity of machine tools as well as the machined components. Hence, the desired surface quality is to be achieved for the functional behavior of mechanical parts.20 The surface roughness has significant influence on fatigue strength, coefficient of friction, lubrication, corrosion resistance, and wear resistance of the machined parts.21 Thus, measuring and characterizing the surface finish has been considered as the predictor of machining performance. However, it is difficult to predict surface roughness due to anisotropic and heterogeneous nature of polyamide materials.

As seen from literature, only limited work has been carried out on cutting aspects of unreinforced and reinforced polyamides drilling. Further, the relationship among the influencing factors and their effects on surface roughness are also not known. Thus, the main objective of this article is to investigate the effect of cutting conditions on surface roughness in high-speed drilling of polyamide with and without 30% glass fibers reinforcing (unreinforced PA6 and PA66 GF30 reinforced) using cemented carbide (K20) tool and comparing with the conventional cutting conditions.

A surface generated by machining is composed of a large number of length scales of superimposed roughness and is generally characterized by three different types of parameters, namely, amplitude parameters, spacing parameters, and hybrid parameters.22 The amplitude parameters such as centerline average surface roughness, root mean square roughness, skewness, kurtosis, maximum peak to valley height are the measures of vertical characteristics of surface deviations. The spacing parameters such as mean line peak spacing, high spot count, and peak count are the measures of horizontal characteristics of surface deviations. On the other hand, the hybrid parameters such as root mean square slope of profile, root mean square wave length, core roughness depth, reduced peak height, valley depth, peak area, valley area are a combination of both the vertical and horizontal characteristics of surface deviations. Thus, considering only centerline average surface roughness is not sufficient to describe the surface finish, though it is the most commonly used roughness parameter. Hence, present study aims at consideration of three different surface roughness parameters, namely, centerline average surface roughness (Ra), maximum peak to valley height (Rz), and peak count (Pc) for the surface texture generated in polyamide drilling.

The conventional technique involves the variation of one parameter at a time while keeping the other parameters at fixed levels and hence, time consuming. Moreover, the traditional method requires huge number of experiments to be performed and also does not include the interactive effects among the parameters. The model development by RSM is a convenient method, which requires minimum number of experiments to be conducted and thus reducing the cost and time.23 Hence, an attempt has been made in this study to develop the RSM-based mathematical models of surface roughness parameters. The experiments have been planned as per full factorial design (FFD), which allows the study of interactions among the variables. The effects of cutting speed and feed rate on centerline average surface roughness, maximum peak to valley height, and peak counts have been analyzed by developing third-order response surface methodology based mathematical models. The parametric analysis indicates the influence of reinforced fiber on surface quality when high-speed drilling is employed.

sec.title: Overview of response surface methodology
sec.p: The RSM is a modeling approach for establishing the relationship between the various process parameters and the responses with the desired criteria and searching the significance of these process parameters on the responses. The RSM is useful for developing, improving, and optimizing the process, which provides an overall perspective of the system response within the design space.23 Using DOE and applying the regression analysis, the modeling of any desired response to several independent process parameters can be obtained. The RSM is employed to describe and identify the influence of interactions of different process parameters on quality characteristic when they are varied simultaneously. This type of design is more practical, economical, and relatively easy to use and is usually chosen when curvature is suspected in the response surface.23 The RSM design procedure includes the selection of proper DOE for the adequate and reliable measurement of response, the development of suitable mathematical model of response surface with best fittings of the experimental data and the representation of interaction effects of process parameters.

sec.title: Experimental database
sec.p:
In the present investigation, the database required for the development of RSM-based model was obtained through FFD of experiments,23 which substantially reduces the number of experiments as compared to classical experimental design. Since the parameters identified in the current study are multilevel variables and their outcome effects are not linearly related as per the authors’ preliminary investigations, it has been decided to use multi-level tests for the cutting conditions. Two work materials, namely, unreinforced polyamide (PA6) and reinforced polyamide with 30% of glass fibers (PA66 GF30), three levels for spindle speed (N), i.e., 4000 rpm (63 m/min), 8000 rpm (126 m/min), and 40,000 rpm (630 m/min) and four levels for feed rate (f), i.e. 1000, 3000, 6000, and 9000 mm/min were considered as the inputs for the development of RSM-based model. The tests employing 40,000 rpm were undertaken using the aerostatic headstock, while the tests at 4000 and 8000 rpm were carried out connecting the tool holder directly to the main spindle of machining center. The cutting parameters were selected aiming to encompass a wide range of applications and covering finish and rough drilling. The experimental layout plan as per FFD consists of 12 sets of process parameter combinations for each of the materials selected and is shown in Table 1. Table 1.
Experimental layout plan as per FFD and the measured values of surface roughness parameters for drilling experiments
Trial No. Cutting conditions Material: PA6 Material: PA66 GF30
N (rpm) f (mm/min) Ra* (µm) RZ* (µm) Pc* (peaks) Ra* (µm) RZ* (µm) Pc* (peaks)
1 4000 1000 10 50.27 76 1.3 10.62 102
2 4000 3000 8.72 46.18 72 1.94 14.02 63
3 4000 6000 4.27 25.88 108 1.56 11.05 63
4 4000 9000 3.76 22.44 110 2.03 13.58 57
5 8000 1000 3.79 22.31 98 0.99 7.28 100
6 8000 3000 4.73 26.5 89 0.93 6.14 70
7 8000 6000 5.5 32.21 97 1.63 12.76 71
8 8000 9000 5.96 33.51 86 1.94 14.14 61
9 40,000 1000 10.36 56.18 64 2.28 14.04 63
10 40,000 3000 7.41 45.18 72 4.16 24.24 64
11 40,000 6000 5.96 35.62 76 1.88 12.49 75
12 40,000 9000 5.48 32.74 86 1.81 12.79 82
*
Average of six measurements.

sec.title: Experimentation
sec.p:
In the present study, unreinforced (PA6) and reinforced with 30% of glass fibers (PA66 GF30) polyamides, supplied by ERTA® were used for the drilling tests. The mechanical and thermal properties of the work materials are listed in Table 2. The experiments were performed on extruded workpiece (disk form) of 50 mm diameter and 12 mm width. Table 2.
Mechanical and thermal properties of PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides
Mechanical and thermal properties PA6 PA66 GF30
Tensile modulus (MPa) 1400 3200
Rockwell hardness M85 M76
Charpy impact resistance (kJ/m2) Without fract. 50
Tensile strength (MPa) 76 100
Melting temperature (°C) 220 255
Density (g/cm3) 1.14 1.29
Coefficient of thermal expansion (<150°C) (m/m.k) 90 × 10–6 50 × 10–6
Coefficient of thermal expansion (>150°C) (m/m.k) 105 × 10–6 60 × 10–6

During machining of reinforced polyamide composites, hard and abrasive glass fibers result in high tool wear and hence it is necessary to employ the appropriate cutting tool. Thus, cemented carbide tool has been selected as the cutting tool material. Grade K20 cemented carbide helical drill of 5 mm diameter with 25o helical angle and 115o point angle manufactured by Guhring oHG (DIN 6539 RN) was used throughout the investigation (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Helical point drill with thinned web DIN 6539 RN used in the drilling experiments.

The drilling experiments were performed as per FFD on a machining center with 11 kW spindle power and a maximum spindle speed of 10,000 rpm. An aerostatic headstock (Figure 2) at 40,000 rpm by Air Turbine Tools (Boca Raton, USA) was used for high-speed machining tests. An appropriate clamping system was devised to fix the polyamide disk in the machining center (Figure 3). The drilled components of PA6 and PA66 GF30 at different cutting conditions are shown in Figure 4 and it was observed that higher the feed rate, shorter the drilling time; however, the chance of damage inside holes increases drastically. Figure 2.
Aerostatic headstock for high speed machining tests (40,000 rpm). Figure 3.
Clamping system of workpiece in the machining center. Figure 4.
Drilled components of: (a) Unreinforced polyamides (PA6); (b) Reinforced polyamides with 30% of glass fibers (PA66 GF30).

The surface roughness was evaluated by three different parameters, namely, centerline average (CLA) surface roughness (Ra), maximum peak to valley height (Rz), and peak count (Pc). Ra is the arithmetic average value of filtered roughness profile determined from deviations about the centerline within the evaluation length and gives general description of surface amplitude, whereas, Rz is the maximum peak to valley height of filtered profile over evaluation length, which is very sensitive to large deviations from mean line and scratches. On the other hand, Pc is the number of profile peaks per unit length. The surface roughness measurement was done according to ISO 4287/1 and DIN 4762 using a Hommeltester T1000 profilometer (Figure 5). Each trial was repeated six times and average of the six measurements of surface roughness parameter values was recorded. The average values of surface roughness parameters for 12 sets of process parameter combinations are given in Table 1. The experimental database is then used to develop the RSM-based surface roughness models. Figure 5.
Profilometer used in the measurements of surface roughness parameters.

sec.title: Development of RSM-based mathematical models
sec.p: In order to understand the effects of process parameters on surface roughness, it is necessary to develop the mathematical models. In the present investigation, each parameter was investigated at multi-levels in order to study the nonlinearity effect of the process parameters. Hence, third-order RSM-based mathematical models for centerline average surface roughness (Ra), maximum peak to valley height (Rz), and peak count (Pc) have been developed with cutting speed (v) and feed rate (f) as the process parameters. The RSM-based mathematical model is of the form: (1)Y=b1+b2v+b3f+b4vf+b5v2+b6f2 +b7v3+b8f3+b9v2f+b10vf2 where, Y is the response, i.e., Ra, Rz, and Pc; b1,…,b10: regression coefficients of polynomial equations are to be determined for each of the surface roughness parameters.

The values of regression coefficients of the mathematical model are determined by:23 (2)B=(XTX)-1XTY where, B is the matrix of parameter estimates, X, the calculation matrix, which includes linear, quadratic, cubic, and interaction terms, XT, the transpose of X, and Y, the matrix of response.

The mathematical models as determined by regression analysis to predict centerline average surface roughness (Ra), maximum peak to valley height (Rz), and peak count (Pc) for PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides drilling are given by:

sec.title: Adequacy checking of surface roughness models
sec.p: The adequacy of the developed models is verified through the coefficient of determination (R2) value after estimating the sum of squares (SS). The R2 quantity is used to test the goodness of fit of the developed RSM-based mathematical models, which provides a measure of variability in observed values of response and can be explained by the controlled process parameters and their interactions23 and is given by (9)R2=SSregressionSSresidualerror+SSregression=SSRSSyy

Here, sum of squares due to regression is given by: (10)SSR=∑iN(yi,pred-y¯i,expt)2 where, yi,expt is the measured response corresponding to data set i; yi,pred, the predicted response corresponding to data set i; y¯i,expt, the overall average of yi,expt; N, the number of data sets in the experimental design matrix.
The sum of squares about the mean is given by: (11)SSyy=∑iN(yi,expt)2-(∑iNyi,expt)2N

The R2 values are presented in Table 3, which indicate the correlation between the experimental and the predicted values of surface roughness parameters. Table 3.
R2values for mathematical models of surface roughness parameters
Surface roughness parameter Sum of squares R2
Regression Residual error
Material: PA6
Centerline average surface roughness 55.4343 2.6993 0.9536
Maximum peak to valley height 1345.78 47.54 0.9659
Peak count 2243.26 166.41 0.9309
Material: PA66 GF30
Centerline average surface roughness 6.0073 1.5807 0.7917
Maximum peak to valley height 160.06 58.97 0.7307
Peak count 2363.94 82.98 0.9661

Equations (3) to (8) are used to test the accuracy of the developed models using the experimental data of FFD. The percentage prediction error of the model for the experimental data set of FFD is given by: (12)δ=100N∑i=1N|yi,expt-yi,predyi,pred| where, yi,expt is the measured value of roughness parameter corresponding to i-th trial; yi,pred, the predicted value of roughness parameter corresponding to i-th trial; and N, the number of trials in FFD.

The percentage prediction error of the models is given in Table 4 and the comparison of the predicted and experimental values of Ra, Rz, and Pc for the experimental data of FFD during drilling of PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides is exhibited in Figures 6, 7, and 8, respectively. As seen from these figures, there exists a close relationship between the experimental and the predicted values and it has been also found that there are no abnormal variations between the experimental and the predicted values. Hence, the developed RSM-based third-order models can be used for the prediction of surface roughness parameters. Figure 6.
Comparison of experimental and predicted values of Ra. Figure 7.
Comparison of experimental and predicted values of Rz.. Figure 8.
Comparison of experimental and predicted values of Pc. Table 4.
Percent prediction error for mathematical models of surface roughness parameters
Surface roughness parameter PA6 PA66 GF30
Centerline average surface roughness 8.31 16.63
Maximum peak to valley height 8.51 15.01
Peak count 5.99 3.28

sec.title: Parametric analysis on surface roughness
sec.p: Equations (3) to (8) are used to predict the surface roughness parameters, namely, centerline average surface roughness (Ra), maximum peak to valley height (Rz), and peak count (Pc) by substituting the values of cutting speed (v) and feed rate (f) within the ranges of the process parameters selected.

A comparison of the estimated centerline average surface roughness (Ra) against the different cutting conditions for PA6 and PA66 GF30 polyamides drilling with K20 cemented carbide drilling is depicted in Figure 9(a)–(c). It is clear from the figure that the Ra values for PA66 GF30 is quite low when compared to PA6 material under all values of feed rate and speed. Moreover, in the case of PA66 GF30, the variation of Ra with respect to feed rate is same for all values of speed considered. On the other hand, for PA6 material, Ra shows decreasing tendency with the increase in feed rate when the speed is at 4000 rpm and 40,000 rpm, while Ra shows an increasing tendency when the speed is at 8000 rpm. A similar behavior of Rz can be seen in Figure 10(a)–(c). Figure 9.
Effect cutting speed and feed rate on Ra. Figure 10.
Effect cutting speed and feed rate on Rz.

Figure 11(a)–(c) illustrates the comparison of Pc for PA6 and PA66 GF30 materials. It is seen that PA66 GF30 outperforms the PA6 under almost all the cutting conditions except at lower values of feed rate and speed. Further, it can be observed that the behavior of Pc is different for different materials for the speed range below 8000 rpm. On the other hand, at 40,000 rpm, the behavior of Pc with respect to feed rate variation is similar for both the materials tested. Figure 11.
Effect cutting speed and feed rate on Pc.

From the above discussions, it can be concluded that PA66 GF30 material shows a better performance with respect to Ra, Rz, and Pc when compared to PA6 work material. Moreover, from the above graphs, it is observed that there is no substantial improvement in the behaviors of Ra, Rz, and Pc during high-speed drilling (40,000 rpm) as compared to low speed drilling (8000 rpm) for both the materials. In this case, the surface roughness is dictated by the cutting temperature, i.e., with the softening of the matrix. At high spindle speed of 40,000 rpm, the heat generated by friction between major and minor cutting edges and work material promotes softening of matrix and hence the surface roughness is not drastically affected by speed-feed combination. However, the earlier investigations18,19 suggested that high-speed drilling in CFRPs is beneficial in minimizing the delamination tendency. But it is not true in our investigations on surface roughness in high-speed drilling of both unreinforced and reinforced polyamides.

The present investigations revealed that better surface quality can be achieved for PA66 GF30 material by employing low feed rate with low to medium speed as compared to PA6 material. This is mainly because of the ductile behaviour of PA66 GF30 material, which causes softening and adhesion of work mateial as compared to PA6. As reported by Davim et al.,24 the presence of glass fibers is also responsible for more brittle behavior of the reinforced polyamide, thus reducing the contact area and promoting lower forces. The lower forces in turn reduces the surface roughness. One more possible reason for the reduction of surface roughness is the lower glass transition temperature of PA66 GF30 polyamide. Figure 12 shows scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of the drilled PA6 polyamide and PA66 GF30 reinforced polyamide work materials. The heat generation due to friction between the cutting edges and the work material leads to the softening of the polymeric matrix, thus impairing surface finish. This effect is clearer in PA6 polyamide; however, in case of the PA66GF30 the glass fiber reinforcement provides a better surface finish. Figure 12.
Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of the work materials (350 × magnification): (a) PA6 polyamide, (b) PA66 GF30 reinforced polyamide.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The polyamides play an important role in modern industries and also in a wide variety of engineering applications. The fibers carry bulk of load and matrix serves as a medium for tranfer of load to fibers in fiber composites. The cutting mechanism in fiber composites is mainly due to the combination of plastic deformation, shearing, and bending rupture and this mechanism depends on flexibility, orientation and toughness of the fibers, which in turn constitute surface texture on the work piece.25 The presence of glass fibers in the polymer matrix increases hardness as well as strength. Due to anisotropic and heterogeneous nature of polyamides, it is very difficult to predict the surface roughness.

The drilling process of brittle thermosets and fibers results in a series of mini-fiber fractures, fiber pullouts and matrix cracking into pieces.26 During drilling of composites, multilayers are cut with a single cutter and hence different mechanisms can be found in the chip formation. At low feed rate values, the chip formation is the continuous-shear type, which is similar to that produced in machining of metals. During drilling at low feed rate, the matrix is sheared continuously and smeared into the gaps among the fibers. The fiber cutting mechanism is composed of fiber cutting, which is microfracture from compression induced shear across the fiber axis and interfacial shearing along the fiber direction. On the other hand, at higher feed rates, the chips produced are discontinuous. At higher feed rates, the cutting mechanism is characterized by compression-induced fracture perpendicular to the fibers and interlaminar shear fracture along the fiber–matrix interface due to bending. Figure 13 presents the forms of the chips obtained after drilling PA66 polyamide at a spindle speed of 4000 rpm (63 m/min) operating at two feed rates, namely, 9000 and 1000 mm/min. The change in the chip form is clearly evidenced in this figure as feed rate is reduced. Figure 13.
Forms of the chips obtained after drilling PA66 polyamide at a spindle speed of 4000 rpm (63 m/min) at two feed rates: (a) 9000 mm/min, (b) 1000 mm/min.

In the present investigation, it is observed that in case of PA66 GF30 drilling, better surface finish was obtained at lower feed rates with low to medium speed range. In general, the reduced surface roughness is mainly due to less fracture and less strain generation in the work materials. The lower feed rates always generate lower cutting forces, which in turn cause less vibration and hence provide better surface finish. The increased feed rate generates more heat between the drill and workpiece and hence tool wear increases, which in turn tend to produce higher surface roughness values. The increase in feed rate usually increases the chatter, which results in incomplete machining at a faster traverse speed, which led to higher surface roughness.14 Furthermore, due to deep-fiber pullouts, higher feed rate produces larger surface roughness.

As seen from Figures 9 and 10, it is observed that, in case of PA6 drilling, a combination of low speed (4000 rpm) and high feed rate (9000 mm/min) resulted in better surface finish. In general, surface roughness increases as feed rate is reduced due to large material flow with cut fibers, whereas, at high speed the chips consist of less deformed matrix material and cut fibers. In addition, higher speeds reduce the cutting forces together with the effect of natural frequency and vibration, thus providing better surface finish. This physical explanation does not agree with the results observed for PA6 material, probably because when cutting speed is elevated to 40,000 rpm associated with high feed rate values, the increase in temperature may cause the melting of material on the machined surface (Figure 12(a)), thus impairing surface finish. As far as the feed rate is concerned, its effect on surface roughness is not as evident in drilling as in the case of cutting with single point tools. When drilling, the contact area between the hole wall and the secondary cutting edge plays a significant role on the surface texture owing to the fact that the marks left by the nose radius are subsequently altered in the contact region. Therefore, a straightforward relationship between feed rate and surface roughness cannot be easily drawn under these circumstances.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In order to analyze the effects of cutting speed and feed rate on surface roughness parameters, namely, centerline average surface roughnes (Ra), maximum peak to valley height (Rz), and peak count (Pc), the RSM-based third-order models were developed. The database required for the development of models were obtained through the drilling experiments planned as per FFD. An experimental study on surface roughness in high-speed drilling of unreinforced polyamide (PA6) and reinforced polyamide with 30% of glass fibers (PA66 GF30) using cemented carbide (K20) tool has been carried out and compared with the conventional cutting conditions. Based on the parametric analysis, the following conclusions are drawn within the ranges of the process parameters selected.
There exist nonlinear relationships between the surface roughness and the cutting conditions and hence justifying the use of third-order RSM-based model.
The Ra and Rz values for PA66 GF30 is low as compared to PA6 material for all values of feed rate and speed.
The Ra and Rz decrease with increase in feed rate when the speed is held at 4000 rpm and 40,000 rpm, whereas they show decreasing tendency when the speed is at 8000 rpm.
With reference to Pc, except at lower values of feed rate and speed, PA66 GF30 material provides better surface finish as compared to PA6 material for all the values of cutting conditions tested.
At high spindle speed of 40,000 rpm, the behavior of Pc with respect to feed rate variation is similar for both the materials tested. On the other hand, the behavior of Pc is different for different materials for the speed range below 8000 rpm.
As compared to PA6 material, PA66 GF30 material provides better surface finish by employing low feed rate with low to medium speed for all the surface parameters tested.
Under high-speed drilling of 40,000 rpm, the surface roughness seems to be less sensitive to feed-speed mainly due to the softening of the matrix.
The developed third-order RSM based models can be used to predict the surface roughness parameters in drilling of unreinforced and reinforced polyamides. However, the validity of the models is limited to range of variables consdered for the investigation. The accuracy of the models can be improved by including additional drilling variables and levels and also by employing higher order models.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Polytechnic Institute of Viseu for supporting the experimental work. Part of the work reported here is sponsored by CAPES/FCT Research Program.

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: None declared.
